image.altText: People inside a building.

props.synopsis: A ratepayers' group is calling for an audit of the $20 million redevelopment of Launceston's heritage-listed Albert Hall for what it says are design flaws.

title.children: Historic hall's $20m modern makeover slammed as 'not fit for purpose'

image.altText: Packets of Tim Tams and Penguins on a table.

props.synopsis: Food manufacturers are responding to high cocoa prices, and a change to the UK's Penguin biscuit may have all but cemented Australia's Tim Tam as the better of the two.

title.children: UK's rival to the Tim Tam can no longer be called chocolate

image.altText: Dozens of union members with matching t-shirts and placards at a rally.

props.synopsis: A week of strike action by public sector unions has wrapped up with no progress on a new pay deal for thousands across health, education, and more.

title.children: No progress on pay deal as Tasmanian public sector flags more action

image.altText: A woman facing away from camera is given a breast screen

props.synopsis: Just over half of Tasmanian women who should be getting regular breast cancer screening are doing so. But with a key service out of action that number could drop even further putting more women at risk. Airlie Wards talks with reporter Meg Whitfield.

title.children: TassieCast: Is cancer detection at risk for some women?

image.altText: Metro bus

props.synopsis: A bus driver has been stood down and Tasmanian authorities are investigating amid allegations that schoolchildren fled the bus in distress.

title.children: Spilled yoghurt sparks alleged 'terrifying' outburst by bus driver

image.altText: A sign outside a tall fence that says Mary Hutchinson Women's Prison

props.synopsis: The family of a young Aboriginal woman who died while in custody in Tasmania say she will be remembered "as a loving and vibrant individual".

title.children: 'Loving, vibrant': Young Aboriginal woman mourned after death in custody

image.altText: Andrew Bolt in a suit and tie at a desk in a TV studio, looking into camera.

props.synopsis: Senior managers at the National Broadband Network intervened to accelerate a home internet upgrade for News Corp pundit Andrew Bolt and resolve a technical problem for a top executive's friend during the final stages of the infrastructure project's rollout.

title.children: 'Throw the kitchen sink at it': NBN Co fast-tracked upgrade for Bolt

image.altText: A young woman and an older lady smiling

props.synopsis: The mother of 21-year-old Finley Bone, who was struck by lightning and later died, says her daughter's life was "taken away in a minute".

title.children: Lightning strike kills talented sportswoman on soccer field

image.altText: A grey-haired, middle-aged man in a dark suit.

props.synopsis: A debate is underway about American democracy, as California's governor campaigns for voters to approve a set of gerrymandered maps.

title.children: 'Race to the bottom': Democrats gerrymander as US democracy strains

image.altText: Banner protesting wind farm proposals

props.synopsis: There are grave concerns that dangerous language and bullying of farmers who are hosting renewable energy projects on their properties could turn into violence.

title.children: 'It's gotten out of hand': Wind farmers fear threat to turn to violence

image.altText: A green cricket helmet sits on a fence at a cricket oval.

props.synopsis: Following the death of 17-year-old Ben Austin, experts, including the former doctor for the Australian cricket team, say more focus needs to be put on neck protection at all levels of the sport.

title.children: Calls for mandatory protection in cricket after tragic Melbourne death

image.altText: Hands beside a dinosaur footprint.

props.synopsis: From dinosaur footprints to volcanic eruptions, First Nations knowledge is helping to drive modern science.

title.children: 'Scientists will never catch up to us': Ancient knowledge helps drive modern science

image.altText: Hundreds of men wearing suits and hats crowded in a street and in buildings.

props.synopsis: Hundreds of thousands of ultra-orthodox Jews have shut down one of the busiest junctions at the entrance to Jerusalem in protest against moves to force them to serve in the Israeli military.

title.children: 'We are against its mere existence': Ultra-orthodox Israelis reject country and army service

image.altText: Anthony Albanese Press Club speech

props.synopsis: Labor came to power in 2022 promising a new form of transparent, accountable politics. As recent incidents have shown, there is little sign of it.

title.children: Albanese government 'leans into a culture of secrecy'

image.altText: a man poses for a photo with his arms over the shoulders of an older woman and a young woman

props.synopsis: On Halloween night in 1936, the tiny, white-haired widow of Harry Houdini made her final attempt to contact him from beyond the grave. Today, the tradition continues.

title.children: Even after the 'final' seance, psychics still try to contact Harry Houdini

image.altText: David Pocock stands in the Senate.

props.synopsis: Independent Senator David Pocock has warned extended Senate question time will continue until Labor releases a secret report. Follow live.

title.children: Pocock issues threat to Labor on Senate games

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Australian navy frigate conducts transit through South China Sea a week after incident
Sussan Ley set up process that led to this morning's Coalition energy meeting
Labor is a 'relic' on nuclear energy, Dan Tehan says

image.altText: A uniformed police officer stands outside a suburban home.

props.synopsis: Police charge a 28-year-old woman with murder after an eight-month-old baby is found dead at a home in Baldivis in Perth's southern suburbs.

title.children: Woman charged with murder of eight-month-old baby in Perth's south

image.altText: A woman with a shaved head and floral dress sits at a table.

props.synopsis: Yorgos Lanthimos continues his journey as the king of absurdist dark comedies with this latest offering, which delves into conspiracy theories in the most bizarre way.

title.children: Emma Stone and Yorgos Lanthimos team up for weirdest film yet

image.altText: A Palestinian child walks past a mural warning against approaching unexploded ordnance.

props.synopsis: Many Palestinians returning to what is left of their homes face the risk of unexploded bombs hidden under rubble, which aid groups say may take decades to clear.

title.children: Gaza is now an 'unmapped minefield' littered with unexploded bombs

image.altText: The old Snowtown bank.

props.synopsis: The South Australian Parole Administrative Review Commissioner will start hearing submissions in December as to why Snowtown killer James Vlassakis should not be released on parole.

title.children: Commissioner to hear submissions on why Snowtown killer should not get parole

image.altText: A life-size bust of Julius Caesar.

props.synopsis: It is time to see if you have been paying attention — test your memory of this week's news cycle here.

title.children: Weekly news quiz: History exams, an unusual gift and the 'storm of the century'

image.altText: ANZ logo

props.synopsis: The Australia share market is higher on Friday but still on track for a weekly loss. ANZ has flagged a $1.1 billion profit hit due to redundancy costs and fines. Follow live.

title.children: ASX on the rise but ANZ shares fall on profit hit

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: ANZ shares drop 0.9% on profit hit
Luci Ellis thinks interest rates will still be cut next year

image.altText: Police tape cordoning off a crime scene.

props.synopsis: Police say a large explosion that rocked the capital overnight was caused by a World War II bomb.

title.children: 'Fireball' and 'panic' as WWII bomb explodes in Solomon Islands capital

image.altText: Alyssa Healy walks from the field after being dismissed in Women's World Cup semifinal.

props.synopsis: Australia captain Alyssa Healy says her side only have themselves to blame as the defence of their World Cup crown comes to an end.

title.children: Aussies rue batting and fielding mishaps in World Cup semi loss to India

image.altText: the torsos of two young children in school uniforms

props.synopsis: Unveiling its choice for word of the year, Dictionary.com explained that it was not quite sure what six-seven meant.

title.children: Gen Alpha's viral 'six-seven' named word of the year

image.altText: People with their fists raised

props.synopsis: Historic legislation has passed that will see the creation of an Indigenous council that will be consulted on laws and policies affecting Indigenous communities.

title.children: Australian-first treaty legislation passes in Victorian parliament

image.altText: A ariel shot of a man standing surrounded by rings of barbed wire.

props.synopsis: Wongarra man Doug Gimesy removes more than 18 kilometres of barbed wire from his property to create a wildlife haven.

title.children: The quiet movement removing barbed wire fences to save wildlife

image.altText: A yacht in the water on a 45 degree angle with a pink sky in the background.

props.synopsis: After a fibreglass yacht ran aground on Lady Elliot Island's pristine reef, a bespoke salvage team worked tirelessly to save the environment from irreparable harm.

title.children: How a yacht salvage team raced against the clock to protect pristine island reef

image.altText: Paleoart showing a pack of Nanotyrannus brazenly attacks a juvenile T. rex.

props.synopsis: A new analysis of a controversial tyrannosaur fossil reveals the dinosaur wasn't a teenage version of T. rex as once thought, but instead a distinct miniature dinosaur.

title.children: Bloody Mary fossil 'flips decades of T. rex research on its head'

image.altText: A Facebook post written by Isla Bell's mother with a photo of Isla smiling underneath

props.synopsis: A judge rules there is enough evidence to send Marat Ganiev and co-accused Eyal Yaffe to trial over the death of the 19-year-old, whose body was found at a tip in Melbourne's south-east last year.

title.children: Melbourne woman Isla Bell's alleged murderer committed to stand trial

image.altText: Woman standing in rain in car park.

props.synopsis: Something is giving shoppers a shock at this Queensland store — and it is not the grocery bill.

title.children: Aldi shoppers report 'ripper' static shocks at supermarket

image.altText: Black looking flowers.

props.synopsis: While red roses have their moment on Valentine's Day, these "black suited" irises come into bloom close to Halloween.

title.children: 'Near black' flowers that bloom just in time for Halloween

image.altText: Tame Impala's Kevin Parker stands hip high in ocean at sunset with goggles, jewellery and cigarette

props.synopsis: From Lily Allen's devastating divorce record to Tame Impala's polarising return, here are October's best new music releases.

title.children: The 10 albums our critics couldn't stop listening to in October

image.altText: Snake catcher Gunter Glasser

props.synopsis: Gunter Glasser has been catching snakes for almost 30 years across Southern Queensland, but October has been an especially busy month.

title.children: Darling Downs 'inundated' with reports of snakes, bites and near misses
